excerpt: The interior walls of this small, 16th-century chapel are lined with the bones & skulls of monks.
detail_description: The Chapel of Bones in Évora is a small 16th-century chapel adorned with the bones and skulls of monks, creating a haunting yet thought-provoking atmosphere. Located near Giraldo Square, it stands next to the famous Igreja de San Francisco cathedral. The chapel's walls are decorated with motifs created from the remains of 5,000 individuals collected from overcrowded cemeteries at the time.
name: Chapel of Bones (Évora)

excerpt: Completed in 1746, this prominent Roman Catholic cathedral offers scenic city views from the tower.
detail_description: The Cathedral of Évora, completed in 1746, is a prominent Roman Catholic cathedral offering scenic city views from its tower. It is one of the most significant cathedrals in Portugal and sits on the highest point of the city, making it a prominent feature of the cityscape.
name: Cathedral of Évora
address: Largo do Marquês de Marialva, 7000-809 Évora, Portugal

excerpt: Granite & marble temple ruin built for the deceased Emperor Augustus in the 1st century A.D.
detail_description: The Roman Temple of Évora, located in the Conde Vila Flor square, is a remarkable ancient ruin built in the 1st century A.D. Initially dedicated to Emperor Augustus, it features impressive Corinthian pillars and stands as a symbol of Roman worship. Over the centuries, it served various purposes including as a mosque during the Moorish period and later as a market and slaughterhouse.
name: Roman Temple of Évora
address: Largo do Conde de Vila Flor, 7000-863 Évora, Portugal

excerpt: Stone aqueduct designed by Francisco de Arruda & built in the 1530s, with a path alongside it.
detail_description: The Agua de Prata Aqueduct, also known as the Evora aqueduct, is a stunning stone structure designed by Francisco de Arruda in the 1530s. Extending for nearly 9 kilometers through various parts of the city's historic center, this well-preserved water canal offers a picturesque path alongside it. The aqueduct showcases an elegant blend of old and new, with its rough stone construction seamlessly integrated into the modern town.
name: Aqueduct Água de Prata

excerpt: Tranquil cobblestone square featuring a 16th-c. fountain, terrace cafes & Gothic architecture.
detail_description: Praça do Giraldo is a charming cobblestone square in Evora, Portugal, known for its 16th-century fountain, Gothic architecture, and bustling atmosphere. Named after Geraldo Sem-Pavor (the Fearless), who played a significant role in ousting the Moors from the city in 1165, this square is a popular meeting place for locals and tourists. It features terrace cafes, boutiques under graceful arcades, and a lively weekend market.
name: Praça do Giraldo

detail_description: The University of Évora, established in 1559, is one of Portugal's oldest educational institutions. Initially managed by the Society of Jesus, it was later repurposed as the National High School of Évora until its reinstatement as a university in 1979. Situated in Évora, Portugal, the university boasts a historic campus with Renaissance architecture and the renowned Cloister of Espirito Santo.
name: University of Évora

detail_description: Giraldo Square Fountain is located in the central district and faces the basilica of St. Andrew. It was named after Giraldo the Fearless, who defeated the Moors in 1165 and became the governor of Evora. The square used to be a Roman market and was later renamed in his honor. The fountain originally sourced water from an aqueduct for public use in ancient times.
name: Giraldo Square Fountain

excerpt: Évora is the capital of Portugal's south-central Alentejo region. In the city's historic center stands the ancient Roman Temple of Évora (also called the Temple of Diana). Nearby, whitewashed houses surround the Cathedral of Évora, a massive Gothic structure begun in the 12th century. The Igreja de São Francisco features Gothic and baroque architecture along with the skeleton-adorned Chapel of Bones.
detail_description: Evora, the capital of Portugal's Alentejo region, is a city steeped in history and culture. Its historic center boasts the ancient Roman Temple of Évora and the Gothic Cathedral of Évora, surrounded by charming whitewashed houses. The Igreja de São Francisco showcases stunning Gothic and baroque architecture, including the eerie Chapel of Bones adorned with skeletons.
name: Evora

excerpt: Neolithic-era monument featuring many stones standing upright in a circle, some with inscriptions.
detail_description: Located just west of Evora near Guadalupe, the Almendres Cromlech, also known as Cromleque dos Almendres, is a Neolithic-era monument dating back over 6,000 years. It is the largest megalithic site on the Iberian Peninsula and predates Stonehenge in England.
name: Almendres Cromlech
address: HW5Q+2G2, Nossa Sra. de Guadalupe, Portugal

detail_description: Nestled within the historic walls of Évora, the Cadaval Palace, or Palacio dos Duques de Cadaval, is a stunning 14th-century gem that offers visitors a glimpse into Portugal's rich heritage. Dominated by the striking Torre das Cinco Quinas (Five Corners Tower), this palace boasts an enchanting Jardim do Paço (Palace Garden) where you can unwind amidst lush greenery.
name: Cadaval Palace

detail_description: Igreja de São João Evangelista, also known as Igreja dos Lóios, is a remarkable monument characterized by the Manueline style. It is part of the Os Loios Convent and stands as an impressive old church in Evora.
name: Igreja de São João Evangelista / Igreja dos Lóios

detail_description: The Jardim Público de Évora, also known as the Public Gardens, is a spacious green area located in the heart of Evora Old Town. It's conveniently close to several attractions such as the central market, Igreja de Sao Francisco, and Chapel of Bones. Visitors can take a leisurely stroll through the gardens or find a peaceful spot for a picnic with local delicacies like bread, cheese, and chourico sausage.
name: Jardim Público de Évora

detail_description: If you're planning an enotourism adventure, the Rota dos Vinhos do Alentejo is a must-visit destination in Évora. This charming hub offers visitors a wealth of information about local wineries and features complimentary tastings of exquisite Alentejan wines. With a rotating selection from various producers each week, you can explore unique flavors without spending a dime! Knowledgeable staff members are on hand to guide you through the tasting experience, sharing insights into the region's rich wine culture.
name: Rota dos Vinhos do Alentejo
address: R. Cinco de Outubro nº 88, 7000-854 Évora, Portugal

detail_description: In Evora, the Igreja da Misericordia stands out as one of the most stunning churches in the area. Built in the 16th century, its unassuming exterior belies a breathtaking interior adorned with a rococo marble door, golden altar, wall frescoes, and hand-painted blue and white azulejo tiles dating back to 1715.
name: Igreja da Misericórdia

detail_description: Jardim Diana is a charming garden located near the Roman Temple, offering a serene atmosphere for visitors to unwind and admire the surrounding scenery. The garden also features an array of statues, adding to its allure as a peaceful retreat in the heart of the city.
name: Jardim Diana

excerpt: Monsaraz is a civil parish of the municipality of Reguengos de Monsaraz, on the right margin of the Guadiana River in the Portuguese Alentejo region, near its border with Spain. The population in 2011 was 782, in an area of 88.29 km². Wikipedia.
detail_description: Monsaraz is a charming civil parish located in the Alentejo region of Portugal, nestled on the right bank of the Guadiana River near the Spanish border. With a population of 782 inhabitants and covering an area of 88.29 km², this picturesque destination offers a serene escape for travelers. Renowned for its historical significance and scenic beauty, Monsaraz is a must-visit for those seeking an authentic Portuguese experience.
name: Monsaraz

excerpt: Imposing Gothic-style church, known for its spooky chapel decorated with human skulls & bones.
detail_description: Igreja e Mosteiro de São Francisco is a Gothic cathedral in Evora, built in honor of St. Francis during the reign of Manuel I. Adjacent to the cathedral is the famous Chapel of Bones, constructed from human skulls and bones collected from overcrowded cemeteries. The chapel's walls are adorned with motifs and its white brick ceiling features death-themed frescoes.
name: Igreja e Mosteiro de São Francisco

detail_description: The Public Library Évora is housed in a 17th-century building near the Convento dos Loios. Established in 1805, it stands as one of Portugal's oldest and most extensive libraries, boasting a remarkable collection that includes 664 incunabula, over 6,000 printed books from the 16th century, handwritten documents, cartography, sheet music, and more than 20 thousand periodical publications.
name: Public Library Évora
address: Largo do Conde de Vila Flor 4, 7000-863 Évora, Portugal

detail_description: Enoturismo Cartuxa is a renowned winery in Alentejo, with a rich wine tradition spanning over 3000 years. Visitors praise the welcoming staff who provide informative tours and extra wine tastings, including the famous Pera Manca. The guided tours offer insights into the winery's history and include wine tastings, allowing guests to savor the exceptional wines. The on-site Enoteca (wine shop) offers an array of wines and knowledgeable staff to assist visitors.
name: Cartuxa - Quinta de Valbom - Fundação Eugénio de Almeida
